Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 1: Child Development

Early Brain Development

The brain grows quickly the first few years of life. The first 3 years are the most rapid growth of neurons and connections in the brain.

The first 8 years are very important for later health and development. By age 6 a child’s brain is 95% of the size of an adult’s brain.

The brain grows its fastest the first 3 years

The brain grows quickly the first few years of life. The first 3 years are the most rapid growth of neurons and connections in the brain.

The first 8 years can build a foundation for the future

You must see evidence that all prescription medications have been ordered by a physician. Over the counter medication does not require physician's instructions. A parent can sign the medication form to have over the counter medication administered (such as Tylenol) without physician's order.

There are factors that play a role in a child’s brain development.

Genes

The child’s genetic makeup is one factor in determining how a child’s brain develops, but only one factor.

Proper Nutrition

A healthy diet started in infancy helps prevent diseases such as high blood pressure and obesity. Poor diets can result in childhood illness, problems with intellectual development, and children being tired, unmotivated, and unable to learn.

Exposure to Toxins & Infections

Exposure to infections and toxins can negatively impact a developing brain.

Child’s Experience with Other People & the World

Nurturing and responsive care for the child’s body and mind is the key to supporting brain development. Children grow and learn best in a safe environment where they are protected from neglect and chronic stress and are given plenty of opportunity to play and explore. Parents and caregivers can support healthy brain growth by speaking, playing with, and caring for their children. By understanding a child’s needs and responding sensitively we help protect children’s brains from stress.
